Headline.Para: Lawmakers Pull All-Nighter to Study 2,232 Page Spending Bill; House members say they relied on coffee, sweets and hardworking staff to plow through complicated document

LeadPara.Para: WASHINGTON—When the 2,232-page government spending bill posted on Wednesday night, Rep. Gary Palmer (R., Ala.) divided it into four sections and broke out the sugar.

"I'm not a big dessert eater, but I confess, after one section I finished, I ate a pack of Bud's Best Cookies," Mr. Palmer said, referring to the Alabama-made treats he gives away in his office. "And then I finished another section, I got up and walked around, got hot tea and then I go back and do another section."

TailParas.Para: With the text of the bill being released in the evening, and votes scheduled for the next morning, House lawmakers had just hours to speed-read through the document. For many, the secret to reviewing the spending bill was caffeine, sugar and hardworking staff who labored through the night, according to interviews with lawmakers and aides.

The mammoth bill increases spending for the military and a wide range of domestic programs, delivering political wins to both parties. But it also includes complicated details on such matters as immigration, health care and gun regulations, which lawmakers wanted to read closely before voting.

"It's not ideal because nobody can digest a 2,000-page bill overnight," said Rep. Tom MacArthur (R., N.J.). "There's not a member of Congress who knows every last thing that's in this bill, but I think all of us are voting on what we do know."

"It's like five Tolstoys," Rep. Don Bacon (R., Neb.) said after the first procedural vote on the bill, noting that he had five or six coffee-fueled aides still poring through it. Leo Tolstoy's "War and Peace," a standard point of comparison for thick volumes, comes in at over 1,000 pages.
After a series of procedural votes Thursday morning, House lawmakers passed the spending bill around lunchtime, and it now heads to the Senate.
The average person reads roughly 184 words a minute, according to a 2012 study published in the Journal of Investigative Ophthalmology & Visual Science. Technical documents can take longer to read.

Rep. Mark Meadows (R., N.C.), chairman of the conservative House Freedom Caucus, which opposed the bill citing its increases in federal spending and rushed release, said he stayed up all night and only made it through roughly 700 pages.
"Unless you can read at a rate of better than 100 pages an hour and stay up all night, there's no way you could have read it," Mr. Meadows said.
Amid the tight deadlines, several Republicans had trouble getting the bill in paper form.

"FYI- The 2200+ page, budget-busting Omnibus has been printing for two hours in my office and still isn't done," Sen. Rand Paul (R., Ky.) tweeted midmorning Thursday. He later updated his Twitter feed later with a photo of himself holding the bill, having finally emerged from the printer.
"Well here it is, all 2,232 budget-busting pages." Mr. Paul has opposed spending bills in the past.
Rep. Thomas Massie (R., Ky.) noted that when the House Rules Committee met Wednesday night to consider the bill, lawmakers on the panel had to share a small number of paper copies.
"I did find it amusing that the Rules Committee only had two or three copies because that's all their copier could do in time," he said.
Those who took a more environmentally friendly route found difficulties too.

"This should be easier to read on your phone," said Rep. Eric Swalwell (D., Calif.) who opted not to print it. "You should be able to tap on the section and go right to it. There should be an app for that."

House Speaker Paul Ryan (R., Wis.) acknowledged Thursday that the week's protracted negotiations over the bill had eaten up some of the time lawmakers would have otherwise had to read and inspect the bill. Mr. Ryan said he was hemmed in by the fact that the government's current funding expires at 12:01 a.m. Saturday.
"We have a hard deadline we're going up against," he said.
He also noted that bill was largely derived from individual spending bills that the House spent months drafting before this week's negotiations. "This bill has been worked on for months," he said.

Rep. Jamie Raskin (D., Md.) had an appearance on C-Span television scheduled for Thursday, where he knew he would be asked about the bill. A law professor by profession, he decided to pull an all-nighter, just like his students did before a final exam.

"So I curled up in bed with thousands of pages of the omnibus when I got home at midnight. I promptly fell asleep at 12:08 a.m.," he said. "So I've been speed-reading it this morning and found both diamonds and daggers in it."
At the Republican Study Committee, five policy staffers divided up the bill and worked all night in time to produce a 40-page analysis before the first procedural vote Thursday morning.
"For policy staff, that's what we live for," said Matt Dickerson, the committee's policy director, who said he typically avoids coffee.
"I had a couple of green teas" over the night, Mr. Dickerson said. "My wife had some brownies out, so I attacked those."
